sections.title: Porcelain and composite veneers with measured preparation
sections.body: Veneers are thin restorations that refine shape, shade, and symmetry. Porcelain veneers are made in the lab for strength and longevity; composite veneers are crafted directly and can be adjusted over time. We keep claims conservative and only recommend veneers when they are the safest option for your teeth.
bullets: Lab-made porcelain veneers for durability and refined translucency
Composite veneers sculpted chairside with the option to revise
Minimal-prep or no-prep approaches considered when enamel allows
Not a whitening shortcut — some discolouration needs other care
We explain pros, limits, and maintenance for each material

faqs.question: Composite vs porcelain — which is right for me?
faqs.answer: Composite is sculpted in-practice and easier to adjust; porcelain is crafted in the lab for strength and stain resistance. We recommend based on goals, enamel health, and how long you want the result to last.

faqs.question: Do veneers ruin teeth?
faqs.answer: We only suggest veneers when the benefit outweighs the enamel we may need to remove. Minimal-prep options are used when safe, and we explain all implications before you decide.

faqs.question: How long do veneers last?
faqs.answer: Longevity varies by material, bite, and care. Porcelain can last many years with reviews and protection; composite may need maintenance or refreshes sooner.

faqs.question: Can I whiten veneers?
faqs.answer: Veneer materials do not whiten like natural teeth. We often whiten natural teeth before shade matching so the result stays balanced.

faqs.question: Do they hurt?
faqs.answer: You may feel temporary sensitivity during preparation or shortly after fitting. We manage comfort carefully and provide guidance to ease recovery.

faqs.question: What if one chips?
faqs.answer: Contact us promptly. Minor chips may be polished or repaired; larger issues might need a replacement or a revised bite assessment.

faqs.question: Are there alternatives?
faqs.answer: Yes. Composite bonding, professional whitening, orthodontics, or crowns may be more suitable depending on your goals. We discuss options before recommending veneers.
